title: Judgment on Moab
shortSummary: Isaiah 16 pronounces a prophetic judgment against Moab, highlighting their pride and impending ruin. The chapter calls for mercy and justice, foretelling Moab's desolation but also emphasizing God's righteous rule through the Davidic throne. It serves as a warning about pride and a call to seek true refuge in God's justice.
timeline: c. 8th century BC - Prophecies during the reign of King Hezekiah of Judah

keyCharacters.name: Moab
keyCharacters.description: A neighboring nation east of Israel, known for pride and rebellion, which is the primary subject of judgment in this chapter.

keyCharacters.name: Ruler of the land
keyCharacters.description: Likely a Moabite leader or king to whom a lamb is sent as a symbol of submission or tribute.

keyCharacters.name: Daughters of Moab
keyCharacters.description: Represent the people of Moab, depicted as vulnerable and wandering in distress.

keyCharacters.name: The Throne in the Tabernacle of David
keyCharacters.description: Symbolizes the Messianic Davidic rule characterized by mercy, truth, and righteousness.

definitions.definition: A rocky fortress city in Edom, near Moab, symbolizing a distant or fortified place.
Crossing points on the Arnon River, marking the border area between Moab and surrounding territories.
To betray or reveal; here it means not to expose or betray the one who wanders or is vulnerable.
A principal city of Moab, whose destruction is mourned in this prophecy.

outline.heading: Call for Submission and Protection
outline.description: The chapter opens with a call to send a lamb to the ruler, symbolizing submission, and urges Moab to protect the outcasts. It anticipates the establishment of a righteous throne in the tabernacle of David, emphasizing mercy and justice.

outline.heading: Condemnation of Moab’s Pride
outline.description: God condemns Moab’s pride, wrath, and lies, predicting lamentation over the destruction of Kirhareseth, highlighting the consequences of arrogance against God’s will.

outline.heading: Desolation of Moab’s Land
outline.description: The prophecy mourns the ruined fields and vineyards of Moab, symbolizing economic and social collapse. Despite Moab’s attempts to seek sanctuary, their prayers will not prevail, indicating God’s judgment is certain.

outline.heading: The Lord’s Decree of Moab’s Decline
outline.description: The chapter concludes with a definitive word from the Lord that within three years Moab’s glory will be despised, and only a small, feeble remnant will remain, underscoring the certainty of divine judgment.

application: Trust in God’s righteous rule rather than worldly pride or power, recognizing that true justice comes from Him.
Show mercy and protect the vulnerable, following the example of sheltering outcasts as a reflection of God’s heart.
Avoid arrogance and wrath, understanding that pride leads to downfall and separation from God’s blessing.
Persist in prayer and seeking God’s help, but align your requests with His will, knowing that not all prayers prevail apart from obedience.

keyVerses.text: And in mercy shall the throne be established: and he shall sit upon it in truth in the tabernacle of David, judging, and seeking judgment, and hasting righteousness.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the coming righteous rule of the Messiah, emphasizing mercy, truth, and justice as the foundation of God's kingdom.

keyVerses.text: We have heard of the pride of Moab; he is very proud: even of his haughtiness, and his pride, and his wrath: but his lies shall not be so.
keyVerses.significance: It warns against pride and wrath, showing that God will not tolerate deceit and arrogance.

keyVerses.text: But now the LORD hath spoken, saying, Within three years, as the years of an hireling, and the glory of Moab shall be contemned, with all that great multitude; and the remnant shall be very small and feeble .
keyVerses.significance: This verse confirms the certainty and timing of Moab’s judgment, illustrating God’s sovereign control over nations.
